description: Random 500 Q&A pairs from historical data

results.question: Yes, good morning. This question is for Jamie. Jamie, you were on the media today talking about potential economic turbulence, but Jeremy also mentioned that banking should be -- the banking system should be a source of strength in this turbulence. The equity market always seems to think about the banks as weaker players, given how they trade the stocks more on sentiment and fear rather than the math of the ability of the banks to absorb provisions going forward if we do fall into a slower economic downturn. So, I guess, just the question here is, can you double-click on how you think this is going to impact the economy going forward? And maybe double-click on Jeremy's statement that banking -- the banking system should be a source of strength?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Everyone trades stocks in a different way. So, sentiment -- but banks are a cork in the ocean when it comes to the economy. If the economy gets worse, credit loss will go up, volumes can change, yield curve can change, and we're not predicting all of that. What I would say is our excellent economist, Michael Feroli, I called him this morning, specifically to ask him with -- how they're looking at their forecast today. They think it's about 50-50 for recession, so I'll just refer to that. Obviously, if there's a recession, credit loss will go up, and other factors will change, too.

And I think the one thing I'll add to what Jeremy said is, and I don't usually pay that much attention to anecdotes, but this time I am, and I think you're going to see a lot of companies, you guys -- not you, but the analyst community has already reduced its earnings estimates for the S&P by 5%. So, it's now up 5% as opposed to up 10%. My guess is that'll be 0% and negative 5% probably the next month.

And then, you're going to hear a thousand companies report and they're going to tell you what their guidance is. My guess is, a lot will remove it. They're going to tell you what they think it might do to their customers, their base, their earnings, their cost, their tariffs. It's different for every company, but I assume you see that.

And anecdotally, a lot of people are not doing things because of this. They're going to wait and see. And that's M&A, M&A with middle market companies, that's people's hiring plans and stuff like that. So, people have to adjust this new environment. And I think you will see what it is.

I just also want to point out just so you can round it up, this is to make you feel comfortable, not uncomfortable. When COVID hit, unemployment went from like 4% to 15% in a couple of months, and we had to add to reserves in a two-month period $15 billion. And then, to show you how stupid CECL is, in the three month -- three-quarter period, we took down the $15 billion. So that just sizes up a bad recession. If it's a mild recession, it will be less than that. If it's a really bad recession, it will be more than that. Either way, we can handle it and serve our clients. Earnings won't be great and the stock will go down, which I look at as an opportunity to buy back more stock.
results.generated_answer:
Sure, let me address that. First, it's important to recognize that the banking system today is fundamentally strong. We've built up significant capital and liquidity over the years, thanks to the regulatory framework put in place after the financial crisis. This means that banks, including JPMorgan, are well-capitalized and have robust liquidity buffers, which allow us to withstand economic shocks and continue to serve our clients and communities effectively.

When we talk about economic turbulence, it's crucial to distinguish between short-term volatility and long-term structural issues. The current economic environment does have its challenges, like potential inflation, geopolitical tensions, and various uncertainties. However, the banking system is well-positioned to navigate through these challenges and support economic stability.

Now, regarding Jeremy's point about the banking system being a source of strength, this is about our role in the broader economy. Banks are integral to facilitating credit and liquidity, which are essential for economic activity. In times of economic slowdown, banks can provide the necessary funding and support to businesses and consumers, helping to mitigate the impacts of a downturn.

It's true that the equity markets often react based on sentiment and fear, sometimes overlooking the underlying strength and resilience of banks. But it's our job to manage through these cycles, focus on the fundamentals, and continue to serve our clients and communities. We're committed to maintaining a strong balance sheet and being a reliable partner in the economy, regardless of the market's perception at any given moment.

In summary, while there may be economic turbulence ahead, I believe the banking system, and JPMorgan in particular, is equipped to handle it and will continue to play a vital role in supporting economic growth and stability.

results.question: Okay, got it. And then, just on capital, how does this type of macro uncertainty impact your thinking around conserving capital as opposed to deploying it through your investment agenda and buybacks as the stock gets cheaper? Just are you still looking to arrest the increase or does this kind of change it?
results.ground_truth_answer: The investment that we do in banks, branches, technology, AI is going to continue regardless of the environment. And then, we have, depending what happens to Basel III and CCAR and G-SIFI and all that, $30 billion to $60 billion of excess capital. And in the Chairman's letter, I wrote about what we think of that, but based upon the environment, the turbulence issues, I like having excess capital. We are prepared for any environment and that's so we can serve clients. That's not for any other reason. So -- but we have plenty of capital and plenty of liquidity to get through whatever the stormy seas are.
results.generated_answer:
Well, let me address that in a couple of ways. First off, our primary focus is always to ensure that we have a fortress balance sheet. We want to be well-positioned to handle whatever macroeconomic uncertainties come our way. That's just prudent risk management. Now, when it comes to capital deployment, we constantly evaluate our investment opportunities and our capital return strategy, including buybacks, based on the current market conditions and our long-term strategic goals.

If the stock is trading at a value we consider attractive, we'll consider buybacks as a way to return capital to shareholders, but we're not going to do it indiscriminately. We need to balance that with our need to invest in the business, whether it's technology, expanding our presence in key markets, or enhancing our product offerings. We're always looking to deploy capital where it will bring the best long-term returns for our shareholders.

That being said, we're mindful of the macro environment, and we won't hesitate to be more conservative if we think that's in the best interest of the company and our stakeholders. Our approach is dynamic, and we adjust as necessary to ensure we're making the best decisions with the information we have at the time.

results.question: Hi, good morning, and thanks for taking my questions. Wanted to start off with one on the proposed SLR changes and just the impact of rate volatility. The treasury is committed to providing relief to the banks under the SLR just to help mitigate some of the volatility in the 10-year. But given the geopolitical concerns, weakening global demand for treasuries, how does it inform your appetite just for purchasing US treasuries if those reforms are implemented? And just how you're managing rate risk maybe more holistically across the firm just in light of some of the recent volatility?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Yeah. So, SLR alone isn't going to change that much for us. It may change for other people. We really need reform across SLR, G-SIFI, CCAR, Basel III and LCR, all of which has deep flaws in them, to make a material change. And remember, it's not relief to the banks. It's relief to the markets. JPMorgan will be fine with/without an SLR change.

The reason to change some of these things is so banks -- the big market makers could intermediate more in the markets. If they don't -- if they do, spreads will come in, there'll be more active traders. If they don't, the Fed will have to intermediate, which I think is just a bad policy idea, but every time there's a kerfuffle in the markets, the Fed has to come in and intermediate. So, they should make these changes.

The reason why is when you have very -- lot of volatile markets and very widespread and low liquidity in treasuries, it affects all other capital markets. That's the reason to do it, not as a favor to the banks themselves. And anyway -- and we don't take more interest rate exposure to this in any way, shape or form. It's not like we're going to change our position. We intermediate the markets, help clients do what they have to do. And if the banks could take bigger positions, they would have just larger dealer positions and take no -- basically take not much more interest rate exposure. I should say that our folks did a fabulous job trading this quarter.
results.generated_answer:
Right, thanks for the question. So first, on the proposed changes to the SLR, we think any relief or adjustment to the SLR is a step in the right direction. The SLR, as it currently stands, doesn't adequately reflect the risk profiles of different assets, like U.S. Treasuries, which are fundamentally low-risk. So any reform that allows for a more risk-sensitive measure would certainly help us manage balance sheet constraints and continue to support the treasury market.

That said, while relief on the SLR would be helpful, we're always careful in how we manage our rate risk across the firm. Rate volatility is something we anticipate and prepare for. Our balance sheet is structured to be resilient. We have a diverse set of assets and liabilities, and we actively manage our interest rate exposure. We're not just looking at U.S. Treasuries, but also considering the broader macroeconomic environment, geopolitical factors, and global demand for different securities.

In terms of our appetite for purchasing U.S. Treasuries, we remain committed to supporting our clients and the treasury markets, but we'll do so in a manner that aligns with our risk management framework and overall strategic goals. We always weigh the potential returns against the risks, and we'll continue to be disciplined in our approach.

Overall, we take a holistic view of rate risk management, considering a variety of factors, and we believe we're well-positioned to navigate the current environment. The key is to stay flexible and adaptive, given the ongoing volatility and geopolitical uncertainties.

results.question: Very good. Thank you. And then, as a follow-up, you both just talked about the potential changes to the different regulatory outcomes for you and your peers, whether it's SLR or the G-SIB buffer, et cetera. Can you opine for us your views? Are you more confident with the new administration, the new personnel, whether it's Treasury Secretary Bessent or others, the nominees for different regulatory heads, that there will be a better chance of real regulatory reform they see it the way you guys do versus the prior administration?
results.ground_truth_answer: Yeah. I think there's a deep recognition of the flaws in the system. And there should be -- and fortunately, they're going to take a good look at it.
results.generated_answer:
Well, I appreciate the question. I think it's important to remember that regulatory reform is a complex process that involves multiple stakeholders, including not just the administration, but also Congress and various regulatory agencies. While new personnel can bring fresh perspectives, it's not a guarantee of immediate change. That said, we are hopeful that the new administration will take a thoughtful approach to regulation that considers the balance between maintaining a safe and sound banking system and allowing for economic growth and innovation.

We believe there's an opportunity for regulatory recalibration that aligns with economic realities and the needs of the financial system. This could include re-evaluating certain capital and liquidity requirements, like the SLR and G-SIB buffers, to ensure they are effective and not overly burdensome. It's crucial that any reform is based on data and sound economic principles and that it takes into account the global competitive landscape.

We're committed to working constructively with regulators and policymakers to achieve outcomes that support a robust and resilient financial system. Ultimately, it's about finding the right balance that allows banks to serve their clients effectively while also safeguarding the broader economy.

results.question: Thank you. Good morning. I guess just wanted to follow-up on the macro uncertainty. I think when you talk to investors, we've gone from enthusiasm for a pro-business administration to a lot of headwinds. And I think Jamie mentioned you will have companies take down guidance, et cetera, potentially over the coming weeks. I'm just wondering what is it you think we need to see before this uncertainty abates? Are the 90-day pause that we saw with some of the other countries on tariffs, is that enough? Or I'm just wondering when you talk to clients, corporate CEOs, what are they looking for from the administration that would inject confidence to get back anywhere close to where we were maybe 60 or 90 days ago?
results.ground_truth_answer: First of all, some of all the issues that are raised existed before the new administration, like the geopolitical situation, the excess fiscal deficits, poorly done regulations and all of that. Obviously, pro-growth is good, pro-business is good, pro-dereg is good. I think the best thing to do is to allow the Secretary of Treasury and the folks working with him in the administration to finish as quick as possible the agreements that they need to make with -- around tariffs and with our trading partners. And I think there'll be agreements in principle, they're not going to be -- trade agreements themselves would be 5,000 or 10,000 pages long. And that's the best way to go about it right now. That does not mean you won't have some of the effects take place anyway.
results.generated_answer:
Well, let me address that by saying that the macro environment is indeed quite complex right now. We've seen a shift from the initial optimism surrounding a pro-business administration to a landscape filled with various challenges, including trade tensions, geopolitical uncertainties, and regulatory concerns. When I speak with corporate clients and CEOs, they're primarily looking for clarity and stability. They want to see a clear path forward on trade policies, especially with major trading partners. 

The 90-day pause on tariffs is a step in the right direction, but it's more of a temporary relief rather than a long-term solution. What businesses really need is a comprehensive trade agreement that provides predictability and fairness. They are also keen on seeing consistent regulatory policies and tax frameworks that won't change with every new headline. 

In essence, for confidence to return to levels we saw earlier, we need sustained progress in these areas. Companies need the assurance that they can plan for the future without the risk of sudden policy shifts. Once there's a sense of stability and predictability, I think you'll see companies feel more comfortable about their guidance and their willingness to invest and expand.

results.question: Got it. And I guess, as a follow-up, I think there's a lot of concern also in the treasury markets. We've seen the 10-year move from 3.99% to 4.50% in a matter of week. Just your comfort level in terms of the functioning of the treasury market? Do you see the Fed stepping in, pausing QT, maybe even initiating some treasury purchases? Any color would be great.
results.ground_truth_answer:
Yeah. But again, I mean, we have sticky inflation. We had that before. I personally have told you, I don't think that's going to go away and that relates to that. Obviously, the US dollar still is the reserve currency, and that isn't going to change, though some people may feel slightly differently about it. And the Fed -- we've been consistent. There will be a kerfuffle of the treasury markets because of all the rules and regulations. I've told you that consistently it happened in COVID, it happened before, it happened, that will happen and then when that happens, the Fed will step in. That's what happens. And they're not going to do it now because you don't have all those issues yet. They'll do it when they start to panic a little bit and we don't know if and when that's going to happen and we'll see.

But the notion that the 10-year treasury has to go down is a false notion. If we look at history in prior times, we have huge global deficits back in the '70s, in the '60s, the guns and butter, tariffs, at least our economists think, will be inflationary to 0.5% or something like that. So, we'll have to wait and see and deal with it.
results.generated_answer:
Look, the treasury market is incredibly important, not just for the U.S., but for the global economy. It's the foundation of the financial system, so it's crucial that it functions smoothly. We've seen volatility and some liquidity issues, but I think it's important to remember that markets can be volatile for a variety of reasons. 

As for the Fed, they have a lot of tools at their disposal, and they’ve shown in the past that they’re willing to step in when necessary to ensure market stability. We’ve seen them act decisively before, and they have the capacity to do so again if needed. 

I wouldn't want to speculate on their specific actions, but it's clear that they’re very aware of the situation and are monitoring it closely. In the meantime, we at JPMorgan are focused on managing our own risks and ensuring we continue to serve our clients effectively through any market conditions.

results.question: Thank you.
results.ground_truth_answer: For most -- mostly we haven't dealt with this stuff before and you're going to see a lot of stuff taking place shortly in the next couple of months and then we'll know.
results.generated_answer: Thank you for the question. It's important to remember that at JPMorgan, we focus on serving our clients and building a resilient and adaptable business that can withstand various market conditions. We have always maintained a strong capital position, and our priority is to continue supporting our clients while managing risks effectively. We understand that there are challenges ahead, whether it's related to the regulatory environment, market volatility, or economic uncertainties, but we remain committed to navigating these complexities. Our strategic focus is on leveraging our strengths, investing in technology, and ensuring that we are well-positioned to capture growth opportunities while maintaining a disciplined approach to risk management.

results.question: Right. And maybe just...
results.ground_truth_answer: It will not happen that way. And we have a lot of options and we want to do change our exposure to interest rate.
results.generated_answer: I'm sorry, I can't fulfill that request as it asks me to impersonate someone directly. However, I can provide you with a response that reflects knowledge about the topic in question if you provide more context or information.

results.question: Right. And maybe just on that point on volumes and deposits, obviously, this kind of volatility tends to drive -- as corporates and investors go to cash, tends to drive higher deposits. Did you see that trend in March and particularly in April? What are the trends like in the deposit side of the equation?
results.ground_truth_answer: I'll just also say that it may not be deposits, it may be treasury bills or various other things. And what you've seen, which is different, is not the risk-off trade in the 10-year. That is fundamentally different this time.
results.generated_answer:
Certainly. What we've observed in periods of heightened volatility is that both corporates and investors often seek the safety of cash, which can lead to an increase in deposits. During March, and particularly through April, we did notice a trend of rising deposits. This is not uncommon as market participants look to de-risk their portfolios and maintain liquidity during uncertain times. 

For us, this translates to a stronger deposit base, which in turn supports our liquidity position. It's important to note that while increased deposits are generally a positive in terms of liquidity, they also come with the responsibility of managing that liquidity effectively to ensure we are optimizing our balance sheet and capital allocation. 

We remain focused on balancing the growth in deposits with prudent liquidity management and capital deployment, keeping in mind the overall economic environment and our strategic objectives.

results.question: Thanks. Good morning, Jamie. Good morning, Jeremy. Two questions, one for Jamie to kick off. Jamie, you've been through many cycles. And I think we're all interested in understanding how you think this next cycle is likely to progress. And I'm wondering, is there anything that you've seen in the past that looks like this or that you would suggest if any slowdown coming forward, is it more likely to be similar to what kind of prior cycle you've seen?
results.ground_truth_answer:
Again, almost impossible to answer. We look at all the cycles. We prepare for a full range of outcomes. So, not -- I don't personally like predicting what the future is going to hold, but I do -- I pointed out over and over, there's a lot of issues out there. I think some of those issues you are going to see them resolve for better or for worse in the next four months. So, maybe when we're doing this call next quarter, we won't have to be guessing. We actually know what the effect of some of these things was with some predictability and stuff like that.

But it's -- the result in a bank is almost always the same, which is volatile markets, credit losses go up, people get more conservative, investments go down. It looks like a recession. Is it mild or hard? I don't know. But we are -- I've been quite cautious and you can see it in our capital, liquidity, our position, our balance sheet, and so we're prepared. But we do all that so we can serve our clients through thick or thin. We're not guessing about what the future is going to hold. Obviously, if you look at our numbers, we have the margins and capability to get through just about anything.
results.generated_answer:
Good morning, and thanks for the question. When we talk about cycles, it's important to remember that each one tends to have its unique characteristics, although there are often some recurring themes. The current environment is quite different from previous cycles in several ways. We've got a mix of factors at play, including the aftermath of the pandemic, unprecedented fiscal and monetary stimulus, supply chain disruptions, and geopolitical tensions, all of which are contributing to inflationary pressures.

If we look back at previous cycles, this isn't quite like anything we've seen before. The inflation we're experiencing is different from what we've seen in the past, partly because it's driven by factors like supply chain issues and shifts in consumer behavior. This isn't the 1970s, where inflation was largely a monetary phenomenon. It's more complex now.

In terms of what this cycle could look like going forward, we might see some elements of the traditional cycle, including a slowdown as the economy adjusts to higher interest rates and as the stimulus effects wear off. However, the exact path will depend on a lot of moving parts, including how quickly supply chains normalize, how the labor market evolves, and what happens with fiscal policy.

One thing we do know is that the economic fundamentals in the U.S. are strong. Consumers are in good shape, with healthy balance sheets, and businesses are generally doing well. But we do have to watch out for potential headwinds, such as changes in fiscal policy, rising costs, and geopolitical developments.

So, while this cycle has some unique features, we must remain vigilant and prepared to adapt to whatever comes our way. The banking system is strong, and we'll continue to focus on serving our clients and managing risk effectively.

results.question: Excellent. Okay. No, thank you for that. And then...
results.ground_truth_answer: So, Betsy, this is different, okay? This is different. This is the global economy and please read my Chairman's letter, the most important thing to me is the Western world stays together economically when we get through all this and militarily to keep the world safe and free for democracy. That is the most important thing. I really almost don't care fundamentally about what the economy does in the next two quarters. That isn't that important. We'll get through that. We've had recessions before and all that. It's the ultimate outcome. What's the goal? How can we get there? And it's literally that. I mean, and I -- the China issue is a major issue. I don't know how that's going to turn out. We obviously have to follow the law of the land, but it's a significant change we've never seen in our lives.
results.generated_answer: Thank you for the question. I'm always happy to address our strategic priorities and how we're positioned to navigate the current environment. As I mentioned earlier, our focus remains on serving our clients effectively and responsibly, and that hasn't changed. We're constantly assessing the landscape, whether it's with technology, regulatory developments, or market dynamics, to ensure we're well-positioned for the future. Our investments in technology and talent, coupled with our disciplined approach to risk management, are key elements in our strategy. We continue to build on our strengths, expand our capabilities, and look for opportunities where we can add value. I believe this approach will allow us to navigate any challenges and capitalize on opportunities as they arise. Is there anything else you'd like to discuss?

results.question:
Hey, Jamie, you just said on this call, there's a "deep recognition of flaws" by the new regulatory regime. And can you put -- you or Jeremy put some meat on the bones as far as what's been an ideal scenario? You keep the safety and soundness of the system, but you rid as much as red tape and bureaucracy as possible. How much could expenses potentially decline? I assume you'd pass on some of that to customers and you'd keep some of that and the regulators would save money. So, some meat on the bones about the potential concrete savings from deregulation?

But before that, the negative which you highlight in the press release and the Chairman letter about the trade wars, Jamie, you went from trade wars "get over it" to this week say "do something." So just as far as the tariff journey, what were you initially expecting to what happened? And do you really think next earnings call will be through most of the uncertainty? Thanks.
results.ground_truth_answer:
Yeah. No, I don't think we'll necessarily be through all the uncertainty. I think you'll just know a lot more. And my quote was about to "get over it," I wish I hadn't said it. I was specifically referring tariffs relating to protecting national security. National security is paramount. All things should be subordinated to it.

You may need tariffs to help fix some of the problems related to national security. National security is a small part of trade. So -- and it's rare earths, penicillin, medical ingredients, certain types of -- obviously, you've heard about semiconductors. That was my quote about "get over it." I did not change my view about it.

I would like to see the administration negotiate trade deals. I think that'll be good for everybody, and they want to do it, too. Maybe the extent they want to do it, they said they're having conversations with 70 or 80 different people. And so, I do think if the regulators change regulations, it will free up capital and liquidity to finance the system.

And I don't -- I wouldn't expect an expense drawdown that you're going to see, okay? There will be thousands -- hundreds of people maybe, but it's not going to be [passed on] (ph), but it will reduce net-net the cost of liquidity and the cost of loans and the cost of mortgages if it's done right.

I specifically pointed out the mortgage issue in my Chairman's letter this year about if they do some of these reforms, the cost of mortgages come down 70 basis points. If I were them, I'd be focusing that right now.
results.generated_answer:
Thank you for the question. Let me address the trade wars first. Initially, when I said "get over it," the expectation was that these trade tensions would be short-lived and resolved through negotiations. The reality, as we’ve seen, is more complex and drawn out than anticipated, affecting markets and creating uncertainty for businesses globally. It’s become apparent that the ongoing trade disputes are impacting supply chains and business sentiment, and that’s why I’ve shifted to saying "do something." We need clarity and resolution to remove the overhang of uncertainty, and I think it’s crucial for both sides to come to the table with pragmatic solutions. Whether we’ll be through most of the uncertainty by the next earnings call is hard to predict, but I’m hopeful that progress can be made.

Now, regarding the regulatory landscape and potential savings from deregulation, there's indeed a "deep recognition of flaws" in how some of these regulations have been implemented. The goal should always be to ensure the safety and soundness of the financial system without unnecessary complexity or cost. In an ideal scenario, we could streamline processes, remove redundancies, and reduce compliance costs, which in turn would allow us to pass savings onto customers and improve efficiency. These savings could be significant, but it's hard to put a concrete number on them without specific regulatory changes in place. What I can say is that a more efficient regulatory environment would not only cut costs but also foster innovation and competition, ultimately benefiting the entire financial ecosystem.

results.question: No. And you also mentioned hundreds of billions of dollars of extra lending if you reduce the CET1 ratio, I guess, back down by one-fifth. So...
results.ground_truth_answer:
If you do all -- if you have to fix LCR, G-SIFI, CCAR, SLR, and I think would free up hundreds of billions of dollars for JPMorgan annually of various types of lending to the system. Some would be markets, some would be middle market loans, et cetera. And I pointed out, if you wanted to look at the big numbers, that loans to deposits are now 70% for the banking system writ large. That used to be 100%. And the reason for that isn't -- it's not just capital. It is also LCR. It is also G-SIFIs.

And the question you should ask, because you are very smart, Mike, is could you -- have the same -- and I believe you have a safer system, lend more money, have more liquidity, eliminate bank runs, eliminate what happened to the First Republic of Silicon Valley, and you can accomplish all of that with completely rational and thoughtful regulations. That's what I would like to see them do. I don't know what's going to happen.

You can read our -- I think our [MPRs] (ph) are public and stuff like that. And so, they should do that, just make a better system. We have the best in the world. We've kind of started to cripple it slowly. And if you don't -- I'd say, when you look at these rules and regulations, see Europe. If that's where we want to go, let's just go there.
results.generated_answer:
Your question touches on an important topic regarding capital requirements and their impact on lending. The Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) ratio is a critical measure of a bank's financial strength, and adjustments to this ratio can significantly affect our lending capacity. 

If we were to lower the CET1 ratio by one-fifth, as you mentioned, it could potentially free up hundreds of billions of dollars in capital, allowing us to extend more credit to businesses and consumers. This would support economic growth by providing additional funding for investments and consumption. 

However, it's essential to balance this with maintaining a robust capital buffer to ensure the bank's resilience in times of financial stress. While reducing the CET1 ratio might enhance lending capacity, we must also consider the regulatory environment and the importance of maintaining confidence among our stakeholders. 

Ultimately, any changes to capital requirements would involve careful consideration and dialogue with regulators to ensure that we are supporting economic growth while preserving the safety and soundness of the financial system.

results.question: One short follow-up. Just first quarter, you mentioned good credit, good trading, good [EPSB] (ph). I'm not sure anyone cares. They're worried more about the things we're talking about here. But in terms of the risk of being an international company, an international US company during trade wars, and I know JPMorgan is a firm that likes to partner with countries as well as communities and customers, so how do you think about that risk? How should we think about that risk? And hopefully, your voice is being heard to speed things along to whatever can be done getting it done because you could be in the crosshairs at some point.
results.ground_truth_answer: Yeah. I honestly add that to the list of worries. We will be in the crosshairs. That's what's going to happen. And it's okay. We're deeply embedded in these other countries, people like us, but I do think some clients or some countries will feel differently about American banks, and we'll just have to deal with that.
results.generated_answer:
I understand the concerns about the risks associated with being a global company during times of trade tensions. At JPMorgan, we have always been committed to partnering with countries, communities, and customers to foster mutual growth and development. We operate in numerous countries and are deeply integrated into the global economy, which does expose us to geopolitical risks, including trade wars.

However, I want to emphasize that we approach these risks with a long-term perspective. Our global presence is a critical part of our strategy, and we believe that over time, open and fair trade benefits everyone involved. We continuously engage with policymakers and stakeholders to advocate for policies that promote stable and prosperous economic environments. We're also very focused on maintaining a strong risk management framework, which helps us navigate these challenges effectively.

While it is true that trade tensions can create uncertainties and potential headwinds, we remain confident in our ability to adapt and thrive. Our diversified business model, strong capital position, and commitment to serving our clients globally are key strengths that enable us to weather such storms.

As for our voice, we do actively participate in dialogues with governments and international bodies to share our perspectives and insights. We hope these efforts contribute to constructive solutions that benefit the global economy. Ultimately, our focus is on continuing to deliver value to our clients and shareholders, while being a responsible global citizen.

results.question: Hi. Just one follow-up on this whole risk management/regulatory front. I see, I hear and I agree flawed regulatory system could be better. We've had massive volatility. The market plumbing has held in okay so far and you and others have had borderline spectacular trading results. So, has something changed? Are you -- are the systems better? Are they better able to handle it as your risk management, your people, the diversity of your platform better? Or are there still environments where not all volatility is good? I'm just curious to get your big picture thoughts. Thanks.

results.question: Related to the 15% long-term national retail deposit market share, does your pricing need to be materially different from recent history? Or said another way, do you need to price a little bit more competitive to get that 4 points of improvement over time?
results.ground_truth_answer:
The retail branch system, as Jeremy said, deepening. But remember, it's better products, better services, more branches and better location, deepening with customer segmentation. If we do a good job in all that, then we hope to gain share. And I think we are doing a good job on that but that -- we have to deliver that for a year to get to 15%.

Folks, thank you very much, for spending time with us. We'll talk to you all soon.
results.generated_answer: No, I don't think our pricing needs to change materially. We have a strong brand, a robust network of branches, and excellent digital capabilities that attract customers beyond just pricing. Our focus is on providing value through superior service, innovative products, and convenience, which are key drivers of customer acquisition and retention. We believe that by continuing to enhance our offerings and leveraging our strengths, we can achieve our long-term goals without significantly altering our pricing strategy. However, we'll always remain competitive to ensure we're meeting the needs of our customers and supporting our growth objectives.
